page.title: 11NATURE RESERVES & "SSSI"s
page.content: Despite the removal of hedgerows and the use of herbicides, the area still has quite a rich limestone flora, par- ticularly along roadside verges (some of which are Nature Reserves). We have two "SSSI"s (Sites of Special Scientific Interest). One is noted for its small population of pasque flower. Intensive grazing by sheep maintains ideal growing conditions, but means the plants rarely flower. Bastard toadflax also grows here. The other SSSI, whose varied flora includes felwort, rock rose, quaking grass and wild thyme, was recently damaged by the extraction of hardcore. The disused railway at Little Bytham is a good habitat. Dragonflies and glow-worms have been seen nearby. A willow at Aunby has dogrose, elder, hawthorn and redcurrant growing in the junction of its trunk and branches!
